		<article class="article-container article--post ">
			<header class="article__header ">
	<div class="article__title-wrapper">
						<h1 class="article__title">Martin Lewis warns over ‘first’ deepfake video scam ad circulating on Facebook</h1>
		</div>

			<div class="article__byline-wrapper">
			
<div class="article__byline">
			<a href="https://techcrunch.com/author/natasha-lomas/">
			Natasha Lomas		</a>
		<span class="article__byline__meta">
							<a href="https://twitter.com/riptari">@riptari</a>
				<span class="text--green"> / </span>
						5 days		</span>
	</div>
		</div>
	
			<div class="article__featured-image-wrapper breakout">
			<img src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/GettyImages-1245156419-e1671450368800.jpg?w=711" class="article__featured-image" />
		</div>
	</header>

			<div class="article-content">
				<p id="speakable-summary">For a glimpse of the AI-generated misery fast accelerating onto our screens thanks to developments in synthetic media that are powering ever more sophisticated forms of deception, check out <a href="https://twitter.com/MartinSLewis/status/1677000805738479618" target="_blank" rel="noopener">this clip</a> of U.K. consumer finance champion Martin Lewis apparently shilling an investment opportunity backed by Elon Musk.</p>
<p>Except of course the footage (also embedded in the below tweet) is an AI-generated deepfake and the investment opportunity is a scam not backed by Lewis (or Musk). The former also makes a point of never appearing in adverts to endorse third party products or services, not that that stops scammers repeatedly misappropriating his image for social media ads to try to trick people into parting with their money…</p>
<div class="embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter">
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-width="550" data-dnt="true">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">WARNING. THIS IS A SCAM BY CRIMINALS TRYING TO STEAL MONEY. PLS SHARE.</p>
<p>This is frightening, it's the first deep fake video scam I've seen with me in it. Govt & regulators must step up to stop big tech publishing such dangerous fakes. People'll lose money and it'll ruin lives. <a href="https://t.co/ZzaBELg1kg">https://t.co/ZzaBELg1kg</a></p>
<p>— Martin Lewis (@MartinSLewis) <a href="https://twitter.com/MartinSLewis/status/1677000805738479618?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">July 6, 2023</a></p></blockquote>
<p></div>
<p>Per Lewis, who was interviewed about the deepfake on <a href="https://twitter.com/GMB/status/1677225397128183808">ITV’s Good Morning Britain</a> (GMB), the video of him shilling an investment scam has been circulating on Facebook. And boy is he livid about that — given he already went to the trouble of suing the tech giant for inaction over scam ads carrying his image, launching defamation litigation <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2018/04/23/facebook-hit-with-defamation-lawsuit-over-fake-ads/">back in 2018</a> in a bid to use his celebrity to shame the tech giant into doing something to stop the scammers.</p>
<p>“This is going around on Facebook at the moment,” Lewis said of the deepfake video. “This, as far as I know, is the first deepfake scam advert that we’ve seen. It’s certainly the first with me in. It’s an absolutely terrifying development. This is still only early stages of the technology. And they are only going to get better.”</p><div class="piano-inline-promo"></div>
<p>“I am viscerally angry about this,” he added. “People will know I have been campaigning for proper regulation of scam adverts for years.”</p>
<p>Lewis settled his defamation suit against Facebook in <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2019/01/23/facebook-agrees-to-do-more-to-tackle-scam-ads-after-celebrity-defamation-lawsuit/">2019</a> after it agreed to make some changes to how it operates, saying it would offer a report ad button to U.K. users to make it easier for them to report dubious ads. It also committed to contribute funding worth 3 million to help set up a citizens’ scam advice service.</p>
<p>But of course that’s a drop in the ocean of money Brits routinely lose to scammers. (Last year losses to U.K. consumers and businesses from fraud and financial scams hit <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2022/nov/07/labour-calls-for-national-strategy-as-annual-losses-hit-1-3bn" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a record 1.3 billion</a>.)</p>
<p>It’s also drop in the ocean of Facebook’s parent Meta’s revenue (full year earnings for 2022 were an eye-watering $116.61 billion), which it generates by selling access to behavioral ad-targeting tools which are powered by its pervasive tracking and profiling of web users.</p>
<p>Meta’s ad tools are essentially doing the heavy lifting for scammers behind ads like the Lewis deepfake — since, once the scammers have crafted an enticing deceptive message, they can plug it straight into the high scale ad-targeting tools it offers to ensure the scam lands in the feeds of users who are most susceptible (<a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/02/04/on-metas-regulatory-headwinds-and-adtechs-privacy-reckoning/">and vulnerable</a>) to being taken in by it, leveraging Meta’s ongoing mass surveillance of web users to reach fresh victims.</p>
<p>Asked for a response to the deepfake a spokesperson for Meta told TechCrunch it’s investigating.</p>
<p>The company also sent us this statement — claiming:</p>
<blockquote><p>We dont allow this kind of advert on our platforms and the original video was proactively removed by our teams, we also removed a number of copycat adverts using the same imagery.</p></blockquote>
<p>However Meta did not provide a direct response when we asked how it had allowed yet another scam bearing Lewis’ explicit liking — albeit, this time, the fake moves and talks in a voice that sounds remarkably like the real deal — to be uploaded to its platform.</p>
<p>While Facebook/Meta gets directly named and shamed by Lewis, the consumer champion is also angry at the U.K. government for failing to tackle the scam ads issue.</p>
<p>In the interview with GMB, he hit out at the lack of response from the government following two consultations on online ads. And while the Online Safety Bill was <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/03/09/online-safety-bill-scam-ads/">expanded to cover scam ads</a> last year, following campaigning by the likes of Lewis, he also attacked the length of time it’s taking to pass the legislation, with the bill still picking its way through parliament — leaving U.K. web users at the mercy of ad platforms’ tepid enforcement of their own T&Cs in the meanwhile.</p>
<p>“We still have an absolute wild west on social media and other Big Tech advertising platforms that allows scammers to get away with impunity,” warned Lewis, adding: “What I want everyone watching to remember is every time you see one of those adverts one of the Big Tech firms is being <em>paid</em> to promote that advert. And these destroy vulnerable people — and many non-vulnerable people’s lives.”</p>
<div class="embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch">
<blockquote class="wp-embedded-content" data-secret="oFMrI0g6Lm"><p><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/03/09/online-safety-bill-scam-ads/">UK expands Online Safety Bill to cover scam ads and eyes wider reforms</a></p></blockquote>
<p></div>
<div class="embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch">
<blockquote class="wp-embedded-content" data-secret="Jzomd4kiIW"><p><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2021/06/30/google-tightens-uk-policy-on-financial-ads-after-watchdog-pressure-over-scams/">Google tightens UK policy on financial ads after watchdog pressure over scams</a></p></blockquote>
<p></div>

hackers raided US government email accounts by exploiting Microsoft cloud bug"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Chinese hackers exploited a flaw in Microsoft\u2019s cloud email service to gain access to the email accounts of U.S. government employees, the technology giant has confirmed.<\/p>\n<p>The hacking group, tracked as Storm-0558, compromised approximately 25 email accounts, including government agencies, as well as related consumer accounts linked to individuals associated with these organizations, according to Microsoft. \u201cStorm\u201d is a nickname used by Microsoft to track hacking groups that are new, emerging or \u201cin development.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Microsoft has not identified the government agencies targeted by Storm-0558. However, Adam Hodge, a spokesperson for the White House\u2019s National Security Council, confirmed to TechCrunch that U.S. government agencies were affected.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cLast month, U.S. government safeguards identified an intrusion in Microsoft\u2019s cloud security, which affected unclassified systems,\u201d Hodge told TechCrunch in a statement. \u201cOfficials immediately contacted Microsoft to find the source and vulnerability in their cloud service. We continue to hold the procurement providers of the U.S. Government to a high security threshold.<\/p>\n<p>Microsoft\u2019s investigation determined that Storm-0558, a China-based hacking group that the firm describes as a \u201cwell-resourced\u201d adversary, gained access to email accounts using Outlook Web Access in Exchange Online (OWA) and Outlook.com by forging authentication tokens to access user accounts.\u00a0In its <a href=\"https:\/\/msrc.microsoft.com\/blog\/2023\/07\/microsoft-mitigates-china-based-threat-actor-storm-0558-targeting-of-customer-email\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">technical analysis of the attack<\/a>, Microsoft explained that the hackers used an acquired Microsoft consumer signing key to forge tokens to access OWA and Outlook.com. Then, the hackers exploited a token validation issue to impersonate Azure AD users and gain access to enterprise email accounts.<\/p>\n<p>Storm-0885\u2019s malicious activity had gone undetected for about a month until customers alerted Microsoft to anomalous mail activity, Microsoft said.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWe assess this adversary is focused on espionage, such as gaining access to email systems for intelligence collection. This type of espionage-motivated adversary seeks to abuse credentials and gain access to data residing in sensitive systems\u201d, said Charlie Bell, Microsoft’s top cybersecurity executive.<\/p>\n<p>Microsoft said the attack was successfully mitigated and that Storm-0558 no longer has access to the compromise accounts. However, the company has not said whether any sensitive data was exfiltrated over the month-long period that the attackers had access.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"h5titIUhdp\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/15\/mandiant-china-hackers-barracuda-espionage-governments\/\">Mandiant says China-backed hackers exploited Barracuda zero-day to spy on governments<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Mandiant says China-backed hackers exploited Barracuda zero-day to spy on governments” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/15\/mandiant-china-hackers-barracuda-espionage-governments\/embed\/#?secret=oke9GGl10n#?secret=h5titIUhdp\" data-secret=\"h5titIUhdp\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Chinese hackers exploited a flaw in Microsoft\u2019s cloud email service to gain access to the email accounts of U.S. government employees, the technology giant has confirmed. brings in Calendly-style availability sharing from Google Calendar"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">On Tuesday, Google released new scheduling-related features for Gmail with Google Calendar integration, including quick event creation and easy availability sharing. Gmail will now have a calendar icon at the bottom of the conversation view, which will have two options \u2014 “Create an event” and “Offer times you’re free.”<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2567935\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2567935\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2567935\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Offer-times-youre-free-or-create-an-event.jpeg?w=680\" alt=\"Offer times you\u2019re free or create an event from Gmail\" width=\"680\" height=\"250\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Offer-times-youre-free-or-create-an-event.jpeg 1332w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Offer-times-youre-free-or-create-an-event.jpeg?resize=150,55 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Offer-times-youre-free-or-create-an-event.jpeg?resize=300,110 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Offer-times-youre-free-or-create-an-event.jpeg?resize=768,283 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Offer-times-youre-free-or-create-an-event.jpeg?resize=680,250 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Offer-times-youre-free-or-create-an-event.jpeg?resize=1200,441 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Offer-times-youre-free-or-create-an-event.jpeg?resize=50,18 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2567935\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Google<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The “Create an event” button is quite straightforward \u2014\u00a0it generates a Google Calendar event with the email subject as the event name and recipients of the email as participants. It also generates a meeting summary in the email body to quickly share the meeting. This feature was already available in Gmail, but was under the three-dot menu.<\/p>\n<p>The new availability-sharing feature opens the calendar in the sidebar and lets you drag slots across different days to share them with the recipient. While you can share your availabilities in an email with multiple people, only the first person accepting a slot will be added to the invite automatically.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2567936\" style=\"width: 520px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2567936\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2567936\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/Negotiate-time-directly-in-Gmail-to-schedule-meetings-faster.gif?w=510\" alt=\"\" width=\"510\" height=\"287\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2567936\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Google<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The scheduling space has seen the rise of multiple tools, including <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/27\/calendly-the-3b-scheduling-startup-acquires-prelude-to-drive-into-the-recruitment-sector\/\">Calendly<\/a>, open source <a href=\"https:\/\/cal.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Cal.com<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/28\/amie-grabbed-7-million-for-its-opinionated-calendar-and-todo-app\/\">Spark Capital-backed Amie<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/15\/vimcal-wants-be-the-most-nifty-calendar-app-on-the-block\/\">Y Combinator-backed Vimcal<\/a>. Google is now offering an easy alternative to these tools when it comes to booking 1:1 meetings and sharing availability.<\/p>\n<p>Google Calendar is on a feature-releasing spree with functions like support for paid meetings and better work location information sharing. The first feature allows freelancers to take <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/11\/google-calendar-now-allows-users-to-take-paid-appointments\/\">paid meetings with a Stripe account integration<\/a>. The second feature, released last week, lets hybrid workers <a href=\"http:\/\/workspaceupdates.googleblog.com\/2023\/07\/adding-more-flexibility-to-working-location-google-calendar.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">share their work location based on the time of the day<\/a> to indicate if they are working from home, the office or another location.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>On Tuesday, Google released new scheduling-related features for Gmail with Google Calendar integration, including quick event creation and easy availability sharing. ollection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1110"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1110"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1110"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=1110"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1110"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":81,"description":"","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/google\/","name":"Google","slug":"google","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/81"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=81"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":38754,"description":"","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/scheduling\/","name":"scheduling","slug":"scheduling","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/38754"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=38754"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=38754"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=38754"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=38754"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=38754"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2567776,"date":"2023-07-12T06:00:14","date_gmt":"2023-07-12T13:00:14","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2567776"},"modified":"2023-07-11T17:26:04","modified_gmt":"2023-07-12T00:26:04","slug":"after-a-worrying-decline-in-2022-consumer-spending-on-apps-returns-to-record-growth","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/12\/after-a-worrying-decline-in-2022-consumer-spending-on-apps-returns-to-record-growth\/","title":{"rendered":"After a worrying decline in 2022, consumer spending on apps returns to record growth"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">After a slowing of the app economy that saw <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/11\/the-app-economy-slowed-for-the-first-time-in-2022-with-consumer-spend-down-2-to-167-billion\/\">consumer spending drop for the first time<\/a> in 2022, things are starting to look up. According to a new report on in-app spending for the first half of 2023 from app intelligence provider <a href=\"http:\/\/data.ai\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">data.ai<\/a>, there’s once again positive growth in mobile consumer spending. The firm reports global in-app spending has rebounded with 5.3% year-over-year growth so far this year, reaching a record $67.5 billion for the first half of 2023. Downloads were also up by 3.2%.<\/p>\n<p>That’s good news for app developers, publishers, and marketers who rely on the app ecosystem’s revenues to sustain their businesses.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2567898\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2567898\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2567898\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"638\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png 1896w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png?resize=150,141 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png?resize=300,282 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png?resize=768,721 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png?resize=680,638 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png?resize=1536,1442 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png?resize=1200,1127 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-1-en.png?resize=50,47 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2567898\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> data.ai<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Data.ai now attributes last year’s decline to consumers “battling inflation,” which had created a “temporary blip” in the long-term sustained growth of the mobile app market, as opposed to something more endemic to the app ecosystem itself — like global markets reaching a point of saturation in terms of consumer spending, for example.<\/p>\n<p>Last year, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/11\/the-app-economy-slowed-for-the-first-time-in-2022-with-consumer-spend-down-2-to-167-billion\/\">consumer spending had declined<\/a> by a slight, but worrying, 2% to $167 billion. It was the first slowdown since the launch of the App Store and came a year after the app market had seen <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/01\/12\/app-annie-global-app-stores-consumer-spend-up-19-to-170b-in-2021-downloads-grew-5-to-230b\/\">19% year-over-year growth<\/a> in 2021. Data.ai’s 2022 findings were based on consumer spending across all app stores, including third-party Android app stores in China, including paid app installs, in-app purchases, and subscriptions.<\/p>\n<p>At the time, data.ai CEO Theodore Krantz remarked how “macroeconomic factors” had been “dampening growth in mobile spend.” However, it wasn’t clear if the decline had been a short-term correction to the rapid growth following the Covid-19 pandemic or a sign the market had peaked, data.ai today explains. The new analysis proves it appears to be the former which — combined with other factors, including inflation — had tightened consumers’ wallets.<\/p>\n<p>The positive growth in consumer spending actually began in late 2022, as is typical around the holiday season as people buy new phones and tablets as gifts and have more free time on their hands to download, use and spend on mobile apps and games.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><img decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-2567899\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"639\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png 1894w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png?resize=150,141 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png?resize=300,282 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png?resize=768,722 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png?resize=680,639 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png?resize=1536,1444 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png?resize=1200,1128 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-2-en.png?resize=50,47 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/p>\n<p>That growth continued into the first half of the years as consumers spent a record $67.5 billion on apps and downloaded 76.8 billion apps globally across the iOS App Store and Google Play. (This analysis does not include the third-party app stores as the full-year report does, we should add.)<\/p>\n<p>Consumer spending was up 5.3% year-over-year during the first half of 2023 with 16% growth in apps, while spending in mobile games remain roughly even, data.ai says. While the lack of growth in games could be concerning, the firm believes growth is likely to soon return to this segment of the market as positive growth had already been seen in March and May 2023 after an earlier low point of -13% in May 2022. The current growth rates for games look similar to that at the start of 2020, ahead of the Covid-19 pandemic, in fact.<\/p>\n<p>iOS growth was also ahead of that of Android, as consumer spending on the App Store was up 5.8% year-over-year in the first half of 2023, while Google Play grew 4.3%. That works out to $43.5 billion in consumer spending on iOS and $24 billion on Android. In addition, iOS accounts for nearly 65% of the total app store spending combined, and even higher in non-gaming apps where it’s 71% of the spend.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2567900\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2567900\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2567900\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"638\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png 1896w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png?resize=150,141 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png?resize=300,282 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png?resize=768,721 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png?resize=680,638 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png?resize=1536,1442 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png?resize=1200,1127 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-3-en.png?resize=50,47 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2567900\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> data.ai<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>TikTok, for example, is a top app for consumer spending with 31% year-over-year growth. It also became the first app to surpass $2 billion in a half year, with $2.1 billion in consumer spending this year so far, up from $1.7 billion in the first half of 2022. Other top non-gaming apps across iOS and Android include Disney+, YouTube, and Duolingo, at 33%, 29%, and 48%, respectively. (YouTube doesn’t monetize through Google Play, however, data.ai notes.)<\/p>\n<p>Max (combined with HBO Max) also did well, with 3% growth in consumer spending compared with the second half of last year, and lifetime consumer spending of $3 billion.<\/p>\n<p>More broadly, top categories for consumer spending included Games, Entertainment, and Social across iOS and Google Play. Other categories delivering at least half a billion in consumer spending also included Productivity, Business, and News & Magazines, which saw strong growth of 32%, 27%, and 25%, also respectively.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2567902\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2567902\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2567902\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"638\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png 1896w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png?resize=150,141 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png?resize=300,282 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png?resize=768,721 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png?resize=680,638 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png?resize=1536,1442 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png?resize=1200,1127 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-4-en.png?resize=50,47 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2567902\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> data.ai<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Top markets for consumer spending so far this year included the U.S., China, and Japan on iOS and the U.S., Japan, and South Korea for Google Play.<\/p>\n<p>Another metric for app ecosystem health is mobile app and game downloads. These have continued to see growth with 76.8 billion new installs this year so far, which would be even with the second half of 2022 and up 3.2% year-over-year.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2567907\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2567907\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2567907\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"638\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png 1896w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png?resize=150,141 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png?resize=300,282 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png?resize=768,721 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png?resize=680,638 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png?resize=1536,1442 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png?resize=1200,1127 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-5-en.png?resize=50,47 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2567907\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> data.ai<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Thanks to Android’s traction in emerging markets like India, Brazil, and Indonesia, Google Play accounts for more than 3x the number of downloads than iOS. Turkey, Russia, and Indonesia, meanwhile, posted the most growth since the second half of 2022.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2567906\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2567906\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2567906\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"638\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png 1896w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png?resize=150,141 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png?resize=300,282 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png?resize=768,721 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png?resize=680,638 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png?resize=1536,1442 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png?resize=1200,1127 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/dataai-h1-2023-market-pulse-chart-6-en.png?resize=50,47 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2567906\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> data.ai<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Download growth is faster on iOS, however, as installs grew 10% year-over-year to 18+ billion, while Google Play installs grew 1.4% year-over-year to 58.7 billion. China, the U.S., and Japan delivered the most iOS downloads, but in terms of growth, Brazil, China, and the U.S. were the markets that delivered.<\/p>\n<p>Games, Tools, and Social were the largest categories by number of downloads, while Games, Productivity, and Tools saw the most growth in absolute downloads. Other top categories included Productivity, Books & Reference, and Health & Fitness, growing 16%, 7%, and 5%, respectively, from the first half of 2022 to the first half of 2023. Travel & Navigations app downloads also grew 19% from the first half of 2019, but this is outpaced by the overall (non-game) app growth of 21%.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2567905\" style=\"width: the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/18\/microsoft-announces-10000-job-cuts-nearly-5-of-its-workforce\/\">roughly 10,000 workers it laid off<\/a> earlier this year. The tech giant is slashing its sales headcount, which is usually one of the areas that technology companies tend to pare down when budgets are reduced. Heck, even Crunchbase News was hit. (Note: I helped build that team while I worked at Crunchbase and am a shareholder in the company from my time of employment.)<\/p>\n<p>But there is change afoot in the realm of tech layoffs.<\/p>\n<p>If you study the <a href=\"https:\/\/layoffs.fyi\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Layoffs.fyi database of tech staff cuts<\/a>, you can spot an interesting trend budding. and mom plead guilty to abortion charges based on Facebook data"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">A Nebraska woman has <a href=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/abortion-charges-nebraska-704b4068ed53791710edad4124f7e750\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pleaded guilty<\/a> to helping her daughter have a medication abortion last year. The legal proceeding against her hinged on Facebook’s decision to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/08\/09\/facebook-helps-cops-prosecute-17-year-old-for-abortion\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">provide authorities<\/a> with private messages between that mother and her 17-year-old daughter discussing the latter’s plans to terminate her pregnancy.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">The case is a telling example of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/27\/digital-data-roe-wade-reproductive-privacy\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">how Big Tech can be tapped<\/a> to help prosecute abortion in the United States, where the Supreme Court in 2022 <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/06\/24\/tech-companies-respond-to-u-s-supreme-court-abortion-decision\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">overturned Roe v. Wade<\/a>, a 1973 decision that legalized abortion. Experts have warned that location data, search histories, emails, text messages and even period- and ovulation-tracking apps can now be used in the prosecution of people who seek an abortion and those who assist them, and this case shows they are right to worry.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Meta, which owns Facebook, could have challenged the legal order to hand over private messages to police, as it and other tech companies sometimes do on various grounds, but it didn’t. The private messages on Facebook Messenger show how the two discussed plans to terminate the pregnancy and destroy the evidence, including instructions from the mother on how to use the pills to end the pregnancy. Those messages directly led law enforcement to acquire a <a href=\"https:\/\/www.documentcloud.org\/documents\/22129545-burgess-search-warrant-cr-22-150\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span class=\"s2\">search warrant<\/span><\/a>.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Police raided the family’s home and seized six smartphones and seven laptops, with data like internet history and emails totaling 24 gigabytes.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Meta did not respond in time to TechCrunch, but last year, the company issued a statement which reads in part:<\/p>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"p1\">Nothing in the valid warrants we received from local law enforcement in early June, prior to the Supreme Court decision, mentioned abortion. The warrants concerned charges related to a criminal investigation and court documents indicate that police at the time were investigating the case of a stillborn baby who was burned and buried, not a decision to have an abortion.<\/p>\n<\/blockquote>\n<p class=\"p1\">TechCrunch has repeatedly asked for more information on what police specifically shared with Meta, and what their suspicions were. Police had initially begun investigating “concerns that a juvenile female…had given birth prematurely supposedly to a stillborn child.”<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p class=\"p1\">As we wrote <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/08\/09\/facebook-helps-cops-prosecute-17-year-old-for-abortion\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">in 2022:<\/a> “A 17-year-old girl and a hastily hidden stillborn seem like something that might deserve closer inspection than a blanket grant to all that kid’s data.” Particularly given the contentious conversation in the U.S. at the time around the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Meta has been loath to take a stance on abortion, but as Irish philosopher Edmund Burke<a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/factcheck-edmund-burke-quote-idUSL1N2PG1EY\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> apparently didn’t say<\/a>, “The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.” The passive stance from Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg is reminiscent of his position against turning Facebook into an “<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2016\/12\/15\/facebook-now-flags-and-down-ranks-fake-news-with-help-from-outside-fact-checkers\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">arbiter of truth<\/a>” in the lead-up to the 2020 presidential election. Zuckerberg at the time acknowledged the importance of not censoring political speech, even when it bordered on misinformation that could impact the democratic process.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Under her plea agreement, the mother, Jessica Burgess, admitted to providing an illegal abortion pill to her daughter after 20 weeks’ gestation, which was at the time illegal. In May, Republican Nebraska governor Jim Pillen <a href=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/transgender-health-care-abortion-ban-nebraska-1a88067bf403559116df7c09e004e472\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span class=\"s2\">signed a bill<\/span><\/a> that bans abortion at 12 weeks of pregnancy, which went into effect immediately.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Burgess also pleaded guilty to false reporting and tampering with human skeletal remains. According to court documents, the mother helped her daughter burn and bury the aborted fetus, which authorities later exhumed from a field north of Norfolk. The court dismissed charges of concealing the death of another person and abortion by someone other than a licensed doctor.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Madison County attorney Joe Smith said this case was the first time he charged anyone with illegally performing an abortion after 20 weeks.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Jessica Burgess is scheduled for sentencing September 22, and she’s looking at two Class IV felony charges and one Class I misdemeanor. In Nebraska, Class IV felonies typically involve a sentencing of up to two years in prison, a $10,000 fine, or both. Class I misdemeanors are sentenced with up to one year in prison, a $10,000, or both.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Celeste Burgess, now 18, was charged last year as an adult and pleaded guilty in May to removing, concealing or abandoning a dead body. Her sentencing hearing is scheduled for July 20, and she faces up to two years in prison.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\">Last summer a man was sentenced to probation after pleading no contest to a misdemeanor for helping the women bury the fetus on his parents’ land.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"moEnxd6sVB\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/04\/how-tech-can-protect-abortion-rights-after-roe-v-wade-decision\/\">8 ways the tech industry can step up to protect abortion rights<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“8 ways the tech industry can step up to protect abortion rights” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/04\/how-tech-can-protect-abortion-rights-after-roe-v-wade-decision\/embed\/#?secret=EY68MI9DXH#?secret=moEnxd6sVB\" data-secret=\"moEnxd6sVB\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>A Nebraska woman has pleaded guilty to helping her daughter have a medication abortion last year. Lewis warns over ‘first’ deepfake video scam ad circulating on Facebook"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">For a glimpse of the AI-generated misery fast accelerating onto our screens thanks to developments in synthetic media that are powering ever more sophisticated forms of deception, check out <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/MartinSLewis\/status\/1677000805738479618\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">this clip<\/a> of U.K. consumer finance champion Martin Lewis apparently shilling an investment opportunity backed by Elon Musk.<\/p>\n<p>Except of course the footage (also embedded in the below tweet) is an AI-generated deepfake and the investment opportunity is a scam not backed by Lewis (or Musk). The former also makes a point of never appearing in adverts to endorse third party products or services, not that that stops scammers repeatedly misappropriating his image for social media ads to try to trick people into parting with their money…<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">WARNING. THIS IS A SCAM BY CRIMINALS TRYING TO STEAL MONEY. PLS SHARE.<\/p>\n<p>This is frightening, it's the first deep fake video scam I've seen with me in it. Govt & regulators must step up to stop big tech publishing such dangerous fakes. People'll lose money and it'll ruin lives. <a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/ZzaBELg1kg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https:\/\/t.co\/ZzaBELg1kg<\/a><\/p>\n<p>— Martin Lewis (@MartinSLewis) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/MartinSLewis\/status\/1677000805738479618?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">July 6, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>Per Lewis, who was interviewed about the deepfake on <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/GMB\/status\/1677225397128183808\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ITV’s Good Morning Britain<\/a> (GMB), the video of him shilling an investment scam has been circulating on Facebook. And boy is he livid about that — given he already went to the trouble of suing the tech giant for inaction over scam ads carrying his image, launching defamation litigation <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/04\/23\/facebook-hit-with-defamation-lawsuit-over-fake-ads\/\">back in 2018<\/a> in a bid to use his celebrity to shame the tech giant into doing something to stop the scammers.<\/p>\n<p>“This is going around on Facebook at the moment,” Lewis said of the deepfake video. “This, as far as I know, is the first deepfake scam advert that we’ve seen. It’s certainly the first with me in. It’s an absolutely terrifying development. This is still only early stages of the technology. And they are only going to get better.”<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>“I am viscerally angry about this,” he added. “People will know I have been campaigning for proper regulation of scam adverts for years.”<\/p>\n<p>Lewis settled his defamation suit against Facebook in <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/01\/23\/facebook-agrees-to-do-more-to-tackle-scam-ads-after-celebrity-defamation-lawsuit\/\">2019<\/a> after it agreed to make some changes to how it operates, saying it would offer a report ad button to U.K. users to make it easier for them to report dubious ads. It also committed to contribute funding worth \u00a33 million to help set up a citizens’ scam advice service.<\/p>\n<p>But of course that’s a drop in the ocean of money Brits routinely lose to scammers. (Last year losses to U.K. consumers and businesses from fraud and financial scams hit <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/money\/2022\/nov\/07\/labour-calls-for-national-strategy-as-annual-losses-hit-1-3bn\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a record \u00a31.3 billion<\/a>.)<\/p>\n<p>It’s also drop in the ocean of Facebook’s parent Meta’s revenue (full year earnings for 2022 were an eye-watering $116.61 billion), which it generates by selling access to behavioral ad-targeting tools which are powered by its pervasive tracking and profiling of web users.<\/p>\n<p>Meta’s ad tools are essentially doing the heavy lifting for scammers behind ads like the Lewis deepfake — since, once the scammers have crafted an enticing deceptive message, they can plug it straight into the high scale ad-targeting tools it offers to ensure the scam lands in the feeds of users who are most susceptible (<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/04\/on-metas-regulatory-headwinds-and-adtechs-privacy-reckoning\/\">and vulnerable<\/a>) to being taken in by it, leveraging Meta’s ongoing mass surveillance of web users to reach fresh victims.<\/p>\n<p>Asked for a response to the deepfake a spokesperson for Meta told TechCrunch it’s investigating.<\/p>\n<p>The company also sent us this statement — claiming:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>We don\u2019t allow this kind of advert on our platforms and the original video was proactively removed by our teams, we also removed a number of copycat adverts using the same imagery.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>However Meta did not provide a direct response when we asked how it had allowed yet another scam bearing Lewis’ explicit liking — albeit, this time, the fake moves and talks in a voice that sounds remarkably like the real deal — to be uploaded to its platform.<\/p>\n<p>While Facebook\/Meta gets directly named and shamed by Lewis, the consumer champion is also angry at the U.K. government for failing to tackle the scam ads issue.<\/p>\n<p>In the interview with GMB, he hit out at the lack of response from the government following two consultations on online ads. And while the Online Safety Bill was <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/09\/online-safety-bill-scam-ads\/\">expanded to cover scam ads<\/a> last year, following campaigning by the likes of Lewis, he also attacked the length of time it’s taking to pass the legislation, with the bill still picking its way through parliament — leaving U.K. web users at the mercy of ad platforms’ tepid enforcement of their own T&Cs in the meanwhile.<\/p>\n<p>“We still have an absolute wild west on social media and other Big Tech advertising platforms that allows scammers to get away with impunity,” warned Lewis, adding: “What I want everyone watching to remember is every time you see one of those adverts one of the Big Tech firms is being <em>paid<\/em> to promote that advert. And these destroy vulnerable people — and many non-vulnerable people’s lives.”<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"oFMrI0g6Lm\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/09\/online-safety-bill-scam-ads\/\">UK expands Online Safety Bill to cover scam ads and eyes wider reforms<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“UK expands Online Safety Bill to cover scam ads and eyes wider reforms” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/09\/online-safety-bill-scam-ads\/embed\/#?secret=n49Z93pAk0#?secret=oFMrI0g6Lm\" data-secret=\"oFMrI0g6Lm\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Jzomd4kiIW\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/06\/30\/google-tightens-uk-policy-on-financial-ads-after-watchdog-pressure-over-scams\/\">Google tightens UK policy on financial ads after watchdog pressure over scams<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; readabilityObject.title: Martin Lewis warns over 'first' deepfake video scam ad circulating on Facebook
readabilityObject.content:
For a glimpse of the AI-generated misery fast accelerating onto our screens thanks to developments in synthetic media that are powering ever more sophisticated forms of deception, check out this clip of U.K. consumer finance champion Martin Lewis apparently shilling an investment opportunity backed by Elon Musk.

Except of course the footage (also embedded in the below tweet) is an AI-generated deepfake and the investment opportunity is a scam not backed by Lewis (or Musk). The former also makes a point of never appearing in adverts to endorse third party products or services, not that that stops scammers repeatedly misappropriating his image for social media ads to try to trick people into parting with their money

WARNING. THIS IS A SCAM BY CRIMINALS TRYING TO STEAL MONEY. PLS SHARE.

This is frightening, it's the first deep fake video scam I've seen with me in it. Govt & regulators must step up to stop big tech publishing such dangerous fakes. People'll lose money and it'll ruin lives. https://t.co/ZzaBELg1kg

Martin Lewis (@MartinSLewis) July 6, 2023

Per Lewis, who was interviewed about the deepfake on ITVs Good Morning Britain (GMB), the video of him shilling an investment scam has been circulating on Facebook. And boy is he livid about that given he already went to the trouble of suing the tech giant for inaction over scam ads carrying his image, launching defamation litigation back in 2018 in a bid to use his celebrity to shame the tech giant into doing something to stop the scammers.

This is going around on Facebook at the moment, Lewis said of the deepfake video. This, as far as I know, is the first deepfake scam advert that weve seen. Its certainly the first with me in. Its an absolutely terrifying development. This is still only early stages of the technology. And they are only going to get better.

I am viscerally angry about this, he added. People will know I have been campaigning for proper regulation of scam adverts for years.

Lewis settled his defamation suit against Facebook in 2019 after it agreed to make some changes to how it operates, saying it would offer a report ad button to U.K. users to make it easier for them to report dubious ads. It also committed to contribute funding worth 3 million to help set up a citizens scam advice service.

But of course thats a drop in the ocean of money Brits routinely lose to scammers. (Last year losses to U.K. consumers and businesses from fraud and financial scams hit a record 1.3 billion.)

Its also drop in the ocean of Facebooks parent Metas revenue (full year earnings for 2022 were an eye-watering $116.61 billion), which it generates by selling access to behavioral ad-targeting tools which are powered by its pervasive tracking and profiling of web users.

Metas ad tools are essentially doing the heavy lifting for scammers behind ads like the Lewis deepfake since, once the scammers have crafted an enticing deceptive message, they can plug it straight into the high scale ad-targeting tools it offers to ensure the scam lands in the feeds of users who are most susceptible (and vulnerable) to being taken in by it, leveraging Metas ongoing mass surveillance of web users to reach fresh victims.

Asked for a response to the deepfake a spokesperson for Meta told TechCrunch its investigating.

The company also sent us this statement claiming:

We dont allow this kind of advert on our platforms and the original video was proactively removed by our teams, we also removed a number of copycat adverts using the same imagery.

However Meta did not provide a direct response when we asked how it had allowed yet another scam bearing Lewis explicit liking albeit, this time, the fake moves and talks in a voice that sounds remarkably like the real deal to be uploaded to its platform.

While Facebook/Meta gets directly named and shamed by Lewis, the consumer champion is also angry at the U.K. government for failing to tackle the scam ads issue.

In the interview with GMB, he hit out at the lack of response from the government following two consultations on online ads. And while the Online Safety Bill was expanded to cover scam ads last year, following campaigning by the likes of Lewis, he also attacked the length of time its taking to pass the legislation, with the bill still picking its way through parliament leaving U.K. web users at the mercy of ad platforms tepid enforcement of their own T&Cs in the meanwhile.

We still have an absolute wild west on social media and other Big Tech advertising platforms that allows scammers to get away with impunity, warned Lewis, adding: What I want everyone watching to remember is every time you see one of those adverts one of the Big Tech firms is being paid to promote that advert. And these destroy vulnerable people and many non-vulnerable peoples lives.
